translated: Connected Discourses 45.1 🔽1. The Chapter on Ignorance 🔽Ignorance 🔽Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: Linked Discourses The Hindrances The Hindrances 1.1 Avijjā (Ignorance) Sutta On One Occasion The Blessed One was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the mendicants:

analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Mendicants!”

analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Avijjā, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samāpattiyā, anvadeva ahirikaṁ anottappaṁ.
analyzed: avijjā bhikkhave pubbaṅgamā akusalānam dhammānam samāpattiyā ahirikam anottappa
translated: “Ignorance is the forerunner in the entry into unskillful qualities, followed by lack of conscience and prudence.

original: Avijjāgatassa, bhikkhave, aviddasuno micchādiṭṭhi pahoti;🔽micchādiṭṭhissa micchāsaṅkappo pahoti;🔽micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācā pahoti;
analyzed: avijjā gatassa bhikkhave aviddasunaḥ micchādiṭṭhi pahoti  micchādiṭṭhissa micchā saṅkappo pahoti  micchā saṅkappassa micchā vācā pahoti
translated: For one who is ignorant and lacks vision, wrong view is possible.🔽For one of wrong view, wrong resolve is possible.🔽For one of wrong resolve, wrong speech is possible.

analyzed: micchā vācassa micchā kammanto pahoti  micchā kammantassa micchā ājīvo pahoti
translated: For one of wrong speech, wrong action is possible.🔽For one of wrong action, wrong livelihood is possible.

analyzed: micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmo pahoti  micchā vāyāmassa micchā sati pahoti
translated: For one of wrong livelihood, wrong effort is possible.🔽For one of wrong effort, wrong mindfulness is possible.

analyzed: micchāsatissa micchāsamādhi pahoti
translated: For one of wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion is possible.

original: Vijjā ca kho, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samāpattiyā, anvadeva hirottappaṁ.
analyzed: vijjā ca kho bhikkhave pubbaṅgamā kusalānam dhammānam samāpattiyāḥ hirottappa
translated: Knowledge is the forerunner in the development of wholesome qualities, with a conscience and shame following along.

original: Vijjāgatassa, bhikkhave, viddasuno sammādiṭṭhi pahoti;🔽sammādiṭṭhissa sammāsaṅkappo pahoti;🔽sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācā pahoti;
analyzed: vijjāgatassa bhikkhave viddasuno sammādiṭṭhi pahoti  sammā diṭṭhissa sammā saṅkappo pahoti  sammā saṅkappassa sammā vācā pahoti
translated: One who has knowledge and vision, Ānanda, can expect to have right view.🔽One who has right view can expect to have right resolve.🔽One who has right resolve can expect to have right speech.

analyzed: sammā vācassa sammā kammanto pahoti  sammā kammantassa sammāājīvo pahoti
translated: One who has right speech can expect to have right action.🔽One who has right action can expect to have right livelihood.🔽One who has right livelihood can expect to have right effort.

analyzed: sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmo pahoti  sammāvāyāmassa sammā sati pahoti
translated: One who has right effort can expect to have right mindfulness.

analyzed: sammā satissa sammā samādhi pahoti iti
translated: One who has right mindfulness can expect to have right concentration.”

analyzed: paṭhama
translated: The first.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya  avijjāvagga

analyzed: upaḍḍha sutta
translated: Half

analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakyesu viharati nagarakaṁ nāma sakyānaṁ nigamo.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sakyesu viharati nagarakam nāma sakyānam nigamaḥ
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling among the Sakyans at a town of the Sakyans named Nagaraka.🔽Then the venerable Ānanda approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, sat down to one side,

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and said to him:

analyzed: upaḍḍham idam bhante brahmacariya yat idam kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā ati
translated: “Venerable sir, this is half of the spiritual life, that is, good friendship, good companionship, good comradeship.”

analyzed: mā hā iva ānanda mā hā iva ānanda
translated: “Don’t say that, Ananda! Don’t say that!

original: Sakalamevidaṁ, ānanda, brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.🔽Kalyāṇamittassetaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṁ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa—ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvessati, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarissati.
analyzed: ānanda brahmacariya yat idam kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā  kalyāṇa mittassa itas ānanda bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkham kalyāṇa sahāyassa kalyāṇa sampavaṅkassa ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvessati ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarissati
translated: Good friendship, good companionship, good comradeship is actually the whole of the spiritual life.🔽It is to be expected that a bhikkhu who has a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade will develop and cultivate the Noble Eightfold Path.

original: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?
analyzed: kathañca ānanda bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: And how, Ananda, does a bhikkhu who has a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade develop and cultivate the Noble Eightfold Path?

original: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ;
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: Here, Ananda, a bhikkhu develops right view, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

analyzed: sammāsaṅkappam bhāveti viveka nissitam pe
translated: He develops right intention …

analyzed: sammāvācam bhāva iti pe
translated: he develops right speech…

analyzed: sammākammantam bhāveti pe  sammāājīvam bhāva iti pe
translated: he develops right action…🔽he develops right livelihood…

analyzed: sammāvāyāmam bhāva iti pe
translated: he develops right effort…

analyzed: sammāsatim bhāva iti pe
translated: he develops right mindfulness…

original: sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ.
analyzed: sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: he develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: It’s in this way, Ananda, that a bhikkhu who has a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade, develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

original: Tadamināpetaṁ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā sakalamevidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.🔽Mamañhi, ānanda, kalyāṇamittaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā
analyzed: tat aminā apetaḥ ānanda pariyāyena veditabbam yathā sakalam eva idam brahmacariya yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā  mamañhi ānanda kalyāṇa mittam āgamma jāti dhammā sattāḥ jātiyā parimuccanti jarā dhammā
translated: “In this way, Ananda, it can be understood how this is a complete method all by itself for maintaining a spiritual life, namely, good friendship, good companionship, good comradeship.

original: sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā
analyzed: sattāḥ jarāya parimuccanti maraṇa dhammā sattāḥ maraṇena parimuccanti soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsa dhammā
translated: For it was by depending on me as a good friend that beings subject to birth have been freed from birth; beings subject to aging have been freed from aging; beings subject to death have been freed from death; beings subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair have been freed from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair.

analyzed: sattā soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsehi parimuccanti
translated: and they are freed from suffering, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair.

original: Iminā kho etaṁ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā sakalamevidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā”ti.🔽Dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: iminā khalu ete ānanda pariyāyena veditabbam yathā sakalam eva idam yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā ati  dutiya
translated: This is another way of understanding how this spiritual life is complete, fulfilled, and perfect, in that it has good people as friends, companions, and associates.”

analyzed: sayutta nikāya
translated: The second section on good people is finished.🔽The Connected Discourses with Ānanda are finished.

analyzed: avijjāvagga
translated: The Collection on Ignorance

analyzed: sāriputta sutta
translated: With Sāriputta

analyzed: sāvatthi nidāna
translated: At Sāvatthī.

original: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:🔽“sakalamidaṁ, bhante, brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā”ti.
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā sāriputtaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā sāriputtaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca  sakalam ida bhante brahmacariya yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā ati
translated: Then Venerable Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said, “Sir, this spiritual life is complete, fulfilled, and perfect, in that it has good people as friends, companions, and associates.”

analyzed: sādhu sādhu sāriputta
translated: “Very good, Sāriputta, very good.

original: Sakalamidaṁ, sāriputta, brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
analyzed: sakalam ida sāriputta brahmacariya yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā
translated: This spiritual life is complete, fulfilled, and perfect, in that it has good people as friends, companions, and associates.

original: Kalyāṇamittassetaṁ, sāriputta, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṁ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa—ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvessati, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarissati.
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittassa ita sāriputta bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkham kalyāṇa sahāyassa kalyāṇa sampavaṅkassa ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvessati ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarissati
translated: It’s to be expected that a monk with good friends, good companions, good comrades will develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

original: Kathañca, sāriputta, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?
analyzed: kathañca sāriputta bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: And how, Sāriputta, does a monk with good friends, good companions, good comrades develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

original: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ
analyzed: idha sāriputta bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissita
translated: Here, Sāriputta, a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ.
analyzed: vossagga pariṇāmim pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: He develops right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: Evaṁ kho, sāriputta, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: evam kho sāriputta bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: It’s in this way, Sāriputta, that a monk with good friends, good companions, good comrades develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

original: Tadamināpetaṁ, sāriputta, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā sakalamidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.🔽Mamañhi, sāriputta, kalyāṇamittaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā
analyzed: tat aminā apeta sāriputta pariyāyena veditabbam yathā sakalam idam brahmacariya yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā  mamañhi sāriputta kalyāṇa mittam āgamma jāti dhammā sattāḥ jātiyā parimuccanti jarā dhammā
translated: “In this way too, Sāriputta, it can be understood how this is a complete spiritual life, perfect as far as it needs to be perfect, supreme as far as it needs to be supreme, lacking nothing as far as it needs to lack nothing.

original: sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā🔽sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti.
analyzed: sattāḥ jarāya parimuccanti maraṇa dhammā sattāḥ maraṇena parimuccanti soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsa dhammā  sattā soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsehi parimuccanti
translated: “Having had me as a good friend, beings subject to birth are freed from birth; beings subject to aging are freed from aging; beings subject to death are freed from death; beings subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair are freed from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair.

original: Iminā kho etaṁ, sāriputta, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā sakalamidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, yadidaṁ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā”ti.🔽Tatiyaṁ.
analyzed: iminā kho eta sāriputta pariyāyena veditabbam yathā sakalam idam brahmacariya yat idam a kalyāṇa mitta tā kalyāṇa sahāya tā kalyāṇa sampavaṅka tā ati  tatiya
translated: “In this way too, Sāriputta, it can be understood how this is a complete spiritual life, perfect as far as it needs to be perfect, supreme as far as it needs to be supreme, lacking nothing as far as it needs to lack nothing.”🔽The third section on good friends is finished.

analyzed: brahmayāna rūpam vata  atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto

analyzed: eka mantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca

original: Addasaṁ khvāhaṁ, bhante, jāṇussoṇiṁ brāhmaṇaṁ sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāyantaṁ.🔽Setā sudaṁ assā yuttā honti setālaṅkārā, seto ratho, setaparivāro, setā rasmiyo,🔽setā patodalaṭṭhi, setaṁ chattaṁ, setaṁ uṇhīsaṁ, setāni vatthāni, setā upāhanā, setāya
analyzed: addasam khvā āha bhante jāṇussoṇim brāhmaṇam sabbasetena vaḷava abhirathena sāvatthiyāḥ niyyāyanta  setā sudam assā yuttāḥ honti seta alaṅkārā setaḥ ratho seta parivāro setāḥ rasmiyaḥ  setā chatta setam setāni vatthāni setā upāhanā setāya
translated: I saw the brahmin Janussoni leaving Sāvatthī in a four-horse chariot with a white parasol held over him and white-heeled shoes on his feet.

original: sudaṁ vālabījaniyā bījīyati.🔽Tamenaṁ jano disvā evamāha:
analyzed: sudam vālabījaniyā bījīyati  tam enam janaḥ disvā evam āha
translated: His horses were white, his chariot was white, his chariot pole was white, his chariot wheels were white, his chariot flag was white, his whip was white, his goad was white, his harness was white, his upholstery was white, his fringe was white, his sunshade was white, his headdress was white, his upper robes were white, his lower robes were white, his shoes were white, and a white fly-whisk with a handle of white ivory was held over him.

analyzed: brahmam vata bho yāna
translated: As people saw him, they said, ‘Brahma’s vehicle, friends!

analyzed: brahmayāna rūpam vata
translated: Brahma’s vehicle!’

original: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye brahmayānaṁ paññāpetun”ti?
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bhante imasmin dhamma vinaye brahmayānam paññāpetun ti
translated: “Lord, is it possible to point out a brahma-vehicle in this Dhamma and Discipline?”

analyzed: sakkaḥ ānandāti bhagavān avoca
translated: “It’s possible, Ānanda,” said the Blessed One.

original: “imasseva kho etaṁ, ānanda, ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṁ:
analyzed: imassa iva kho eta ānanda ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacana
translated: ‘This is a designation for the noble eightfold path.

original: ‘brahmayānaṁ’ itipi, ‘dhammayānaṁ’ itipi, ‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo’ itipīti.🔽Sammādiṭṭhi, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosavinayapariyosānā hoti, mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.
analyzed: brahmayānaḥ itipi dhammayānaḥ itipi anuttaraḥ saṅgāma vijayaḥ itipi iti  sammādiṭṭhi ānanda bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāga vinaya pariyosānā hoti dosa vinaya pariyosānā hoti moha vinaya pariyosānā hoti
translated: It is also called the vehicle of Brahmā, the vehicle of Dhamma, and the unsurpassed victory in battle.’🔽Right view, when developed and cultivated, has the removal of greed as its culmination, its goal, and its focus.

original: Sammāsaṅkappo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosavinayapariyosāno hoti, mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.🔽Sammāvācā, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappaḥ ānanda bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ rāga vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti dosa vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti moha vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti  sammā vācā ānanda bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāga vinaya pariyosānā hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānā hoti
translated: Right intention …🔽Right speech …

original: Sammākammanto, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.
analyzed: sammā kammantaḥ ānanda bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ rāga vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti
translated: Right action …

original: Sammāājīvo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.
analyzed: sammāājīvaḥ ānanda bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ rāga vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti
translated: Right livelihood, when developed and cultivated, has the removal of greed as its culmination, its goal, its fruit, its outcome.

original: Sammāvāyāmo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.🔽Sammāsati, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.
analyzed: sammāvāyāmaḥ ānanda bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ rāga vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti  ānanda bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāga vinaya pariyosānā hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānā hoti
translated: Right effort, when developed and cultivated, has the removal of greed as its culmination, its goal, its fruit, its outcome.🔽Right mindfulness, when developed and cultivated, has the removal of greed as its culmination, its goal, its fruit, its outcome.

original: Sammāsamādhi, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.🔽Iminā kho etaṁ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā imassevetaṁ ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṁ:
analyzed: sammāsamādhi ānanda bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ rāga vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti dosa pe moha vinaya pariyosānaḥ hoti  iminā kho ete ānanda pariyāyena veditabbam yathā imassa iva etam ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacana
translated: Right concentration, when developed and cultivated, has the removal of greed as its culmination, its goal, its fruit, its outcome.🔽It is in this way, Ananda, that this Noble Eightfold Path is the path leading to the cessation of greed, the path leading to the cessation of hatred, the path leading to the cessation of delusion.

analyzed: brahmayānaḥ itipi dhammayānaḥ itipi anuttaraḥ saṅgāma vijayaḥ itipi iti
translated: It is in this way, Ananda, that this Noble Eightfold Path is the supreme development of the faculties.”

analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
analyzed: idam vatvāna sugataḥ atha aparam etat avoca satthā
translated: Having said this, the Sublime One, the Teacher, further said this:

analyzed: yassa saddhā ca paññā ca
translated: “One who has faith and wisdom,

analyzed: dhammā yuttā sadā
translated: The Dhamma is always yoked to the pole,

analyzed: hirī īsā manaḥ
translated: The yoke-strap is conscience, the horse is the mind,

analyzed: sati ārakkha sārathi  ratho sīla parikkhāro
translated: Mindfulness is the guard of the chariot.🔽The chariot is the equipment of virtue,🔽The axle is jhāna, the wheel is energy,

analyzed: jhāna kkhaḥ cakka vīriyaḥ  upekkhā dhura samādhi
translated: Equanimity is the pole of the chariot,

analyzed: anicchā parivāraṇa
translated: Non-desire is the covering.

analyzed: a byāpādaḥ a vihisā  vivekaḥ yassa āvudha
translated: Non-ill will and harmlessness,🔽Solitude is his weapon.

analyzed: titikkhā camma sannāhaḥ
translated: Patience is his armor,

analyzed: yogakkhemāya vattati
translated: He proceeds to safety.

analyzed: sambhūta  brahmayānam anuttara
translated: This is the supreme divine vehicle,🔽Which is produced from oneself.

analyzed: niyyanti dhīrāḥ lokamhā
translated: The wise ones depart from the world,

analyzed: aññadatthu jayam jayanti
translated: Having conquered, having conquered again and again.”

analyzed: catuttha
translated: The fourth.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, are concluded.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya  avijjāvagga
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is the fourth section.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.

original: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu …pe… ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho sambahulāḥ bhikkhū yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu pe ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.

original: “Idha no, bhante, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā amhe evaṁ pucchanti:
analyzed: idha no bhante añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakāḥ amhe evam pucchanti
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.

analyzed: kimatthiye āvuso samaṇe gotame brahmacariyam vussati iti
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.🔽The Connected Discourses with Māra, the Evil One, is concluded.

original: Evaṁ puṭṭhā mayaṁ, bhante, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākaroma:
analyzed: evam puṭṭhāḥ bhante tesam añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam evam byākaroma
translated: When asked this, we reply:

original: ‘dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññatthaṁ bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatī’ti.
analyzed: dukkhassa kho āvuso pariññattham bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati iti
translated: ‘Friend, the holy life is lived under the Blessed One for the full understanding of suffering.’

original: Kacci mayaṁ, bhante, evaṁ puṭṭhā evaṁ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva bhagavato homa,🔽na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākaroma, na ca
analyzed: bhante evam puṭṭhāḥ evam byākaramānāḥ vutta vādinaḥ ca iva bhagavataḥ  na ca bhagavantam abhūtena abbhācikkhāma dhammassa ca anudhammam byākaroma na ca
translated: “When we are asked this, we reply in this way. Are we stating what has been said by the Blessed One and not misrepresenting him with what is contrary to fact?

original: koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchatī”ti?
analyzed: koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anuvādaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgacchati iti
translated: Do we explain in accordance with the Dhamma in such a way that nothing which provides a ground for censure can be legitimately deduced from our assertion?”

original: “Taggha tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ puṭṭhā evaṁ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva me hotha,🔽na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhatha, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākarotha, na ca koci sahadhammiko
analyzed: taggha tumhe bhikkhave evam puṭṭhāḥ evam byākaramānāḥ vutta vādinaḥ ca iva me hotha  na ca mama abhūtena abbhācikkhatha dhammassa ca anudhammam byākarotha na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ
translated: “Certainly, bhikkhus, when you are asked this, you state what has been said by me and do not misrepresent me with what is contrary to fact.

analyzed: vāda anuvādaḥ gārayham ṭhānam āgacchati
translated: You explain in accordance with the Dhamma in such a way that nothing which provides a ground for censure can be legitimately deduced from your assertion.

original: Dukkhassa hi pariññatthaṁ mayi brahmacariyaṁ vussati.
analyzed: dukkhassa hi pariññattham mayi brahmacariyam vussati
translated: For the holy life is lived under me for the full understanding of suffering.

original: Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:
analyzed: sace vaḥ bhikkhave añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakāḥ evam puccheyyu
translated: If wanderers who follow other paths ask you:

original: ‘atthi panāvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti, evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha:
analyzed: atthi pana āvuso maggaḥ atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāya ati evam puṭṭhāḥ tumhe bhikkhave tesam añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam evam byākareyyātha
translated: ‘Is there a path, friends, is there a way for the full understanding of this suffering?’🔽you should say:

original: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti.
analyzed: atthi kho āvuso maggaḥ atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāya ati
translated: ‘There is a path, there is a way for the full understanding of this suffering.’

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo, katamā paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave maggaḥ katamā paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāya ati
translated: And what is that path, what is that way for the full understanding of this suffering?

analyzed: ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi
translated: right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo, ayaṁ paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti.
analyzed: bhikkhave maggaḥ ayam paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāya ati
translated: This is the path, this is the way for the full understanding of this suffering.’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyāthā”ti.🔽Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: evam puṭṭhāḥ tumhe bhikkhave tesam añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam evam byākareyyātha ati  pañcama
translated: If wanderers who follow other paths ask you this, you should answer in such a way.”

translated: “The destruction of greed, hatred, and delusion is the deathless.🔽This noble eightfold path is the path leading to the deathless, namely, right view … right concentration.

analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave sammāvācā
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is right speech?

original: Yā kho, bhikkhave, musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī—
analyzed: yā kho bhikkhave musāvādā veramaṇī pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī samphappalāpā veramaṇī
translated: Abstinence from false speech, abstinence from malicious speech, abstinence from harsh speech, and abstinence from gossip.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammā vācā
translated: This is called right speech.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave sammākammanto
translated: And what, monks, is right action?

original: Yā kho, bhikkhave, pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, abrahmacariyā veramaṇī—
analyzed: yā kho bhikkhave pāṇa atipātā veramaṇī adinna ādānā veramaṇī abrahmacariyā veramaṇī
translated: It is this: abstaining from killing living beings, abstaining from taking what has not been given, abstaining from sexual misconduct.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammākammanto
translated: This is called right action.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave sammāājīvaḥ
translated: And what, monks, is right livelihood?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvitaṁ kappeti—
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ micchāājīvam pahāya sammāājīvena jīvitam kappeti
translated: Here, monks, a noble disciple, having abandoned wrong livelihood, earns his living by right livelihood.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammāājīvaḥ
translated: This is called right livelihood.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave sammāvāyāmaḥ
translated: And what, monks, is right effort?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati,🔽uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam anuppādāya chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati  uppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya chandam janeti pe
translated: Here, monks, a monk generates desire for the non-arising of unarisen evil unwholesome states, he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.🔽He generates desire for the abandoning of arisen evil unwholesome states, he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti …pe…
analyzed: anuppannānam kusalānam dhammānam uppādāya chandam janeti pe
translated: He generates desire for the arising of unarisen wholesome states, he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.🔽He generates desire for the continuance, non-disappearance, strengthening, increase, and fulfilment by development of arisen wholesome states, he makes an effort, arouses energy, applies his mind, and strives.

original: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati—
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: He generates desire for the persistence, non-disappearance, increase, growth, abundance, development, and fulfilment of arisen wholesome thoughts.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammāvāyāmaḥ
translated: This is called right endeavour.

analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave sammā sati
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is right mindfulness?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body in the body, ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating feelings in feelings, ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
analyzed: citte citta anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating mind in mind, ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ—
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating phenomena in phenomena, ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammā sati
translated: This is called right mindfulness.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave sammāsamādhi
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is right concentration?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati  vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati  pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ ca sampajāno sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the first jhana, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination.🔽With the stilling of thought and examination, he enters and dwells in the second jhana, which has internal placidity and unification of mind and consists of rapture and pleasure born of concentration, without thought and examination.

original: yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the fading away as well of rapture, he dwells equanimous and, mindful and clearly comprehending, he experiences pleasure with the body; he enters and dwells in the third jhana of which the noble ones declare: ‘He is equanimous, mindful, one who dwells happily.’

original: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati—
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and displeasure, he enters and dwells in the fourth jhana, neither painfull nor pleasant, which has purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave sammāsamādhi iti
translated: This is called right concentration.”

analyzed: aṭṭhama
translated: The eighth chapter.

analyzed: sayutta nikāya  avijjāvagga  sūkasutta
translated: Connected Discourses 45.9 🔽1. The Chapter on Ignorance 🔽A Parrot

analyzed: sāvatthi nidāna
translated: Linked Discourses The Simile of the Sunshade The Simile of the Rice Sheaf At Sāvatthī.

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālisūkaṁ vā yavasūkaṁ vā micchāpaṇihitaṁ hatthena vā pādena vā akkantaṁ hatthaṁ vā pādaṁ vā bhindissati, lohitaṁ vā uppādessatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave sāli sūkam vā yava sūkam vā micchā paṇihitam hatthena vā pādena vā akkantam hattham vā pādam vā bhindissati lohitam vā uppādessati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “It’s impossible, monks, it cannot happen that a rice or barley shoot would grow from a seed that’s been properly planted, but that it would pierce the seed and emerge on the opposite side.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: micchā paṇihita ttā bhikkhave sūkassa
translated: Because the seed is planted wrongly.

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu micchāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā micchāpaṇihitāya
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave saḥ vata bhikkhu micchāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā micchāpaṇihitāya
translated: In the same way, it’s impossible, monks, that a monk whose view is wrongly oriented, whose practice is wrongly oriented,

original: maggabhāvanāya avijjaṁ bhindissati, vijjaṁ uppādessati, nibbānaṁ sacchikarissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: magga bhāvanāya avijjam bhindissati vijjam uppādessati nibbānam sacchikarissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: would pierce ignorance, give rise to knowledge, and realize extinguishment.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: micchā paṇihita ttā bhikkhave diṭṭhiyā
translated: Because his view is wrongly oriented.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālisūkaṁ vā yavasūkaṁ vā sammāpaṇihitaṁ hatthena vā pādena vā akkantaṁ hatthaṁ vā pādaṁ vā bhindissati, lohitaṁ vā uppādessatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave sāli sūkam vā yava sūkam vā sammāpaṇihitam hatthena vā pādena vā akkantam hattham vā pādam vā bhindissati lohitam vā uppādessati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It’s possible that a rice grain or a barley grain placed on its point might pierce the hand or foot and draw blood.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Sammāpaṇihitattā, bhikkhave, sūkassa.🔽Evameva kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya
analyzed: sammā paṇihita ttā bhikkhave sūkassa  evam eva kho bhikkhave saḥ vata bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya
translated: Because the point is well-directed.

original: maggabhāvanāya avijjaṁ bhindissati, vijjaṁ uppādessati, nibbānaṁ sacchikarissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: magga bhāvanāya avijjam bhindissati vijjam uppādessati nibbānam sacchikarissati iti ṭhānam etat vijjati
translated: In the same way, it’s possible that a monk whose view is well-directed and whose development of the path is well-directed will pierce ignorance, give rise to clear knowing, and realize extinguishment.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: sammā paṇihita ttā bhikkhave diṭṭhiyā
translated: Because his view is well-directed.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya maggabhāvanāya avijjaṁ bhindati, vijjaṁ uppādeti, nibbānaṁ sacchikarotīti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya magga bhāvanāya avijjam bhindati vijjam uppādeti nibbānam sacchikaroti iti
translated: And how does a monk whose view is well-directed and whose development of the path is well-directed pierce ignorance, give rise to clear knowing, and realize extinguishment?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissita
translated: There is the case where a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right resolve dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right speech dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right action dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right livelihood dependent on seclusion…

original: vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ.
analyzed: vossagga pariṇāmim pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: He develops right effort dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right mindfulness dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya maggabhāvanāya avijjaṁ bhindati, vijjaṁ uppādeti, nibbānaṁ sacchikarotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya magga bhāvanāya avijjam bhindati vijjam uppādeti nibbānam sacchikaroti iti
translated: It’s in this way, monks, that a monk with right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, & right concentration—with a mind well established in the eight factors of the noble path—breaks through to the four noble truths. He breaks through to them as they actually are present: stress, the origination of stress, the cessation of stress, & the way of practice leading to the cessation of stress.”

original: Atha kho nandiyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho nandiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho nandiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi 🔽sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho nandiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When they had concluded their greetings and cordial talk, he sat down to one side and said to the Blessed One:🔽“Master Gotama, I have heard this: ‘The contemplative Gotama does not bow down to old age, does not stand up for old age, does not do homage to old age.’

original: “kati nu kho, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbānaṅgamā honti nibbānaparāyanā nibbānapariyosānā”ti?
analyzed: kati nu kho bho gotama dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatāḥ nibbāna aṅgamāḥ honti nibbāna parāyanāḥ nibbāna pariyosānā ati
translated: “How many things, when developed and cultivated, lead to Nibbāna?”

original: “Aṭṭhime kho, nandiya, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbānaṅgamā honti nibbānaparāyanā nibbānapariyosānā.
analyzed: aṭṭhime kho nandiya dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatāḥ nibbāna aṅgamāḥ honti nibbāna parāyanāḥ nibbāna pariyosānāḥ
translated: “Eight things, Nandiya, when developed and cultivated, lead to Nibbāna.

analyzed: pe sammāsamādhi

analyzed: ime kho nandiya aṭṭha dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatāḥ nibbāna aṅgamāḥ honti nibbāna parāyanāḥ nibbāna pariyosānā ati
translated: These eight things, when developed and cultivated, lead to Nibbāna.”

translated: “And how, monks, does a monk with a friend with good qualities develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotī”ti.

translated: It’s to be expected that a monk with good friends, companions, and associates will develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṁ dosavinayapariyosānaṁ

translated: And how does a bhikkhu who has a good friend develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

analyzed: moha vinaya pariyosānam pe sammā samādhim bhāveti rāga vinaya pariyosānam dosa vinaya pariyosāna  moha vinaya pariyosāna
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release. … He develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti, ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti iti
translated: This is how a bhikkhu who has a good friend develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”🔽The first section for recitation on the good person is finished.

translated: There is the case where a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right resolve dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right mindfulness dependent on seclusion…

analyzed: moha vinaya pariyosāna

translated: in the same way a monk who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path inclines to unbinding, trends to unbinding, streams to unbinding.

translated: And how does a monk develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path so that he inclines to unbinding, trends to unbinding, streams to unbinding?🔽There is the case where a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

translated: He develops right resolve… right speech… right action… right livelihood… right effort… right mindfulness… right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

translated: That’s how a bhikkhu, developing and cultivating the noble eightfold path, makes it his constant practice to incline to Nibbāna, to head towards Nibbāna, to lead towards Nibbāna.”🔽The sixth section on those who incline to Nibbāna is finished.

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release. … He develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appamatto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotīti.

analyzed: appamādaḥ tesam dhammānam aggam akkhāyati  appamattassa ita bhikkhave bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkha ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvessati ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarissati

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appamatto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appamatto ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotī”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.

analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: In the same way, a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: And how, monks, does a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim pe
translated: Here, monks, a monk develops right view, which is based on seclusion, on dispassion, on cessation, resulting in the relinquishment of the fetters. …

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotīti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti iti
translated: That’s how a monk develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path so as to abandon the five lower fetters.”

(The rest is as in the description of the development of the path in the “description of development” in the “Perils” chapter, but with the following differences: in the first jhāna, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the second jhāna, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the third jhāna, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the fourth jhāna, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the attainment of the base of infinite space, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the attainment of the base of infinite consciousness, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the attainment of the base of nothingness, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; in the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, “the five hindrances” is replaced by “the five lower fetters”; and in the case of the six direct knowledges, the “five higher fetters” is replaced by “the five lower fetters.”)

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti, sabbe te pathaviṁ nissāya pathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhāya evamete balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ye keci bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti sabbe te pathavim nissāya pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya evam ete bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti
translated: “Monks, whatever activities are undertaken, all of them are supported by the earth and based on the earth.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti.

translated: In the same way, a monk, supported by virtue and based on virtue, develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?

translated: “And how, monks, does a monk, supported by virtue and based on virtue, develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṁ dosavinayapariyosānaṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti rāga vinaya pariyosānam dosa vinaya pariyosāna
translated: There is the case where a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right resolve dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

analyzed: moha vinaya pariyosānam pe sammā samādhim bhāveti rāga vinaya pariyosānam dosa vinaya pariyosāna  moha vinaya pariyosāna
translated: He develops right speech dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right action dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right livelihood dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right effort dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right mindfulness dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotīti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti iti
translated: He develops right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti, sabbe te pathaviṁ nissāya pathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhāya evamete balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ye keci bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti sabbe te pathavim nissāya pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya evam ete bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti
translated: “Just as any constructions of strength that are done, are all done based on the earth, established on the earth,🔽so too, a monk based on virtue, established on virtue, develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāveti ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkaroti
translated: “And how, monks, does a monk based on virtue, established on virtue, develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?

translated: And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu develop and make much of the noble eightfold path that leads to the complete destruction of suffering?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti amatogadhaṁ amataparāyanaṁ amatapariyosānaṁ …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti amatogadhaṁ amataparāyanaṁ amatapariyosānaṁ.

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release. … He develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotīti.

translated: It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu develops and makes much of the noble eightfold path that leads to the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti, sabbe te pathaviṁ nissāya pathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhāya evamete balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ye keci bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti sabbe te pathavim nissāya pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya evam ete bala karaṇīyā kammantā karīyanti
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever bodily work is undertaken, all that is dependent on earth, established on earth.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti.

translated: In the same way, a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path that is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?

translated: And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path that is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṁ nibbānapoṇaṁ nibbānapabbhāraṁ …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṁ nibbānapoṇaṁ nibbānapabbhāraṁ.

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view … right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkarotī”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.

translated: It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path that is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.”

analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ye keci ime bīja gāma bhūta gāmāḥ vuḍḍhim virūḍhim vepullam āpajjanti
translated: “Just as, bhikkhus, whatever kinds of seeds and seedlings, annuals and perennials,🔽

original: sabbe te pathaviṁ nissāya pathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhāya evamete bījagāmabhūtagāmā vuḍḍhiṁ🔽virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjanti;🔽evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ
analyzed: sabbe te pathavim nissāya pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya evam ete bīja gāma bhūta gāmā vuḍḍhi  virūḍhim vepullam āpajjanti  evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgika
translated: “Just as, bhikkhus, whatever grasses, scrubs, and trees there are, small or large, they all stand on the earth as their basis and foundation, and it is in dependence on the earth that they grow, increase, and become large;

original: maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto vuḍḍhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ pāpuṇāti dhammesu.
analyzed: maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ vuḍḍhim virūḍhim vepullam pāpuṇāti dhammesu
translated: so too, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the Noble Eightfold Path stands on the earth as his basis and foundation, and it is in dependence on the earth that he grows in the True Dhamma.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto vuḍḍhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ pāpuṇāti dhammesu?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ vuḍḍhim virūḍhim vepullam pāpuṇāti dhammesu
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the Noble Eightfold Path stand on the earth as his basis and foundation, and it is in dependence on the earth that he grows in the True Dhamma?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim pe
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release. … He develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release. …🔽It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the Noble Eightfold Path so that he may understand the course that is in accordance with reality.

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ

translated: “It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu, depending on virtue, establishing himself in virtue, having virtue as his support,

original: bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto vuḍḍhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ pāpuṇāti dhammesū”ti.
analyzed: bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ vuḍḍhim virūḍhim vepullam pāpuṇāti dhammesu iti
translated: develops and cultivates the Noble Eightfold Path and thereby achieves growth, increase, and abundance in wholesome qualities.”

analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave himavantam pabbata rājam nissāya nāgā kāyam vaḍḍhenti balam gāhenti  te tattha kāyam vaḍḍhetvā balam gāhetvā kusobbhe otaranti kusobbhe otaritvā mahāsobbhe
translated: “Relying on the Himalayas, the king of mountains, elephants grow in bulk and strength.🔽Having grown in bulk and strength there, they descend to the pools,

original: otaranti, mahāsobbhe otaritvā kunnadiyo otaranti, kunnadiyo otaritvā mahānadiyo otaranti,
analyzed: otaranti mahāsobbhe otaritvā kunnadiyaḥ otaranti kunnadiyaḥ otaritvā mahā nadiyaḥ otaranti
translated: where they descend into the water and bathe and drink. Having bathed and drunk, they emerge and stand on the bank, shaking off the water from their limbs. Then, having shaken off the water, they smear the earth with their trunks, and with their tusks they tear up lotus stalks and roots and eat them.

original: mahānadiyo otaritvā mahāsamuddaṁ otaranti, te tattha mahantattaṁ vepullattaṁ āpajjanti kāyena;

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto mahantattaṁ vepullattaṁ pāpuṇāti dhammesu.

translated: In the same way, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops and makes much of the noble eightfold path that leads to the complete destruction of suffering, and he reaches greatness and vast extent in the Dhamma.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṁ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto mahantattaṁ vepullattaṁ pāpuṇāti dhammesu?

translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu develop and make much of the noble eightfold path that leads to the complete destruction of suffering, and how does he reach greatness and vast extent in the Dhamma?

translated: There is the case where a monk develops mindfulness as a factor for awakening dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

analyzed: rukkhasutta
translated: He develops analysis of qualities as a factor for awakening … persistence as a factor for awakening … rapture as a factor for awakening … serenity as a factor for awakening … concentration as a factor for awakening … equanimity as a factor for awakening dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽“And how does a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, develop & pursue the noble eightfold path, making it familiar, ripening it, bringing it to maturity?

analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave rukkhaḥ pācīna ninnaḥ pācīna poṇaḥ pācīna pabbhāraḥ
translated: “There is the case where a monk develops right view dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.🔽He develops right resolve … right speech … right action … right livelihood … right effort … right mindfulness … right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: So mūlacchinno katamena papateyyā”ti?🔽“Yena, bhante, ninno yena poṇo yena pabbhāro”ti.
analyzed: saḥ mūla chinno katamena papateyya ati  yena bhante ninnaḥ yena poṇaḥ yena pabbhāro ti
translated: “And how does a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, enter & remain in the first absorption?🔽There is the case where a monk—quite secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities—enters & remains in the first absorption, which consists of rapture & pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought & evaluation.🔽“And how does a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, enter & remain in the second absorption?🔽There is the case where a monk—with the stilling of directed thoughts & evaluations—enters & remains in the second absorption, which consists of rapture & pleasure born of concentration, unification of awareness free from directed thought & evaluation.

original: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro
translated: “And how does a monk, depending on virtue, established on virtue, enter & remain in the third absorption?🔽There is the case where a monk—with the fading of rapture—remains equanimous, mindful, & alert, and senses pleasure with the body. He enters & remains in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous & mindful, he has a pleasant abiding.’🔽“And how does a monk

analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro
translated: And how does a monk develop the noble eightfold path, make much of the noble eightfold path?

analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissita

translated: He develops right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.🔽Catutthaṁ.🔽Saṁyutta Nikāya 45.153

translated: In the same way, when a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path, he abandons evil unwholesome states and does not take them up.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto vamateva pāpake akusale dhamme, no paccāvamati?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ vamatā iva pāpake akusale dhamme no paccāvamati  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissita
translated: And how does a bhikkhu develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path so that he abandons evil unwholesome states and does not take them up?

analyzed: sūkasutta
translated: A rice grain

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālisūkaṁ vā yavasūkaṁ vā sammāpaṇihitaṁ hatthena vā pādena vā akkantaṁ hatthaṁ vā pādaṁ vā bhindissati lohitaṁ vā uppādessatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave sāli sūkam vā yava sūkam vā sammāpaṇihitam hatthena vā pādena vā akkantam hattham vā pādam vā bhindissati lohitam vā uppādessati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: “Suppose there was a rice grain or a seed of rice or a seed of millet that was intact, unspoiled, undamaged by wind or sun, fertile, and well-filled. If it was planted in good soil in a well-prepared field, would it grow, increase, and mature?”🔽“Yes, sir.”

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “Why is that?”

analyzed: sammā paṇihita ttā bhikkhave sūkassa
translated: “Because the rice grain is well-placed.”

original: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya maggabhāvanāya avijjaṁ bhindissati, vijjaṁ uppādessati, nibbānaṁ sacchikarissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitāya diṭṭhiyā sammāpaṇihitāya magga bhāvanāya avijjam bhindissati vijjam uppādessati nibbānam sacchikarissati iti ṭhānam etat vijjati
translated: “In the same way, it’s possible that a monk with a well-placed view, who develops and cultivates the path, will destroy the various kinds of ignorance, give rise to true knowledge, and realize Nibbāna.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gimhānaṁ pacchime māse ūhataṁ rajojallaṁ, tamenaṁ mahāakālamegho ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti;

translated: Linked Discourses The Cowherds’ Questions The Cowherds’ Questions, First Version “Mendicants, in the last month of summer, a great untimely cloud rains down on the heated and dusty earth, and that dust disappears and settles down right there.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti.

translated: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path … wipes out three things right there. …”

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti?

translated: “And how does a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path wipe out three things right there?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim
translated: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which are based on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go. …

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānasaḥ antaradhāpeti vūpasameti iti
translated: That’s how a monk, developing and cultivating the noble eightfold path, makes the unarisen wholesome states arise and the arisen wholesome states grow and increase.”

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppannaṁ mahāmeghaṁ, tamenaṁ mahāvāto antarāyeva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti;🔽evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāyeva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave uppannam mahā megha tam enam mahā vātaḥ antarāya iva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti  evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāya iva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti
translated: “Monks, suppose a great cloud had arisen, and a great wind arose and dispersed it, causing it to vanish and cease.🔽In the same way, monks, a monk developing and cultivating the noble eightfold path makes unarisen unwholesome states not arise and arisen unwholesome states to be abandoned.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāyeva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāya iva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti
translated: And how does a monk, developing and cultivating the noble eightfold path, make unarisen unwholesome states not arise and arisen unwholesome states to be abandoned?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim
translated: He develops right action dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right livelihood dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right effort dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right mindfulness dependent on seclusion…🔽He develops right concentration dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāyeva antaradhāpeti vūpasametī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme antarāya iva antaradhāpeti vūpasameti iti
translated: “It’s in this way, monks, that a monk, developing & pursuing the noble eightfold path, abandons the non-virtuous thoughts that have arisen and, having arisen, do not lead to disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, peace, direct knowledge, self-awakening, or unbinding.”

translated: Then, after six months, when the great ocean had been churned by the storm-wind blowing from the west, it would be buffeted by the storm-wind blowing from the east.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvayato ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroto appakasireneva saṁyojanāni paṭippassambhanti, pūtikāni bhavanti.

translated: In the same way, when a bhikkhu develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path, his fetters are abandoned and his inherent tendencies are brought to an end.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvayato ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroto appakasireneva saṁyojanāni paṭippassambhanti, pūtikāni bhavanti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhuno ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvayataḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarotaḥ appa kasirena iva sayojanāni paṭippassambhanti pūtikāni bhavanti
translated: And how does a bhikkhu develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path so that his fetters are abandoned and his inherent tendencies are brought to an end?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṁ bhāveti …pe… sammāsamādhiṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ …🔽evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvayato ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroto appakasireneva saṁyojanāni paṭippassambhanti, pūtikāni bhavantī”ti.🔽Dasamaṁ.🔽Saṁyutta Nikāya 45.159
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim 🔽evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhuno ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvayataḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarotaḥ appa kasirena iva sayojanāni paṭippassambhanti pūtikāni bhavanti iti 🔽dasama 🔽sayutta nikāya
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view … right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

translated: In the same way, a monk who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path abandons the unskillful, non-noble path. …

original: ye dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā, te dhamme abhiññā pajahati, ye dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā, te dhamme abhiññā sacchikaroti, ye dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā, te dhamme abhiññā bhāveti.

translated: He abandons through direct knowledge those things that should be abandoned through direct knowledge. analyzed: seyyathidaṃ rūpa upādānakkhandho pe viññāṇa upādānakkhandho
translated: They are the material form aggregate subject to clinging, the feeling aggregate subject to clinging, the perception aggregate subject to clinging, the volitional formations aggregate subject to clinging, and the consciousness aggregate subject to clinging.

analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgika  maggam bahulīkarontaḥ ye dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā te dhamme abhiññā parijānāti pe  ye dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā te dhamme abhiññā bhāveti  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim
translated: “And how does a bhikkhu develop and make much of the noble eightfold path so as to abandon the five lower fetters?🔽Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view … right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyam aṭṭhaṅgika

analyzed: ye dhammāḥ abhiñā pahātabbā te dhamme abhiññā pajahati ye dhammāḥ abhiññā sacchikātabbā
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops right view … right concentration, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.🔽It is in this way that a bhikkhu develops and makes much of the noble eightfold path so as to abandon the five higher fetters.

analyzed: te dhamme abhiñā sacchikaroti ye dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā te dhamme abhiññā bhāveti iti
translated: He directly knows those things that should be directly known. He fully understands those things that should be fully understood. He abandons those things that should be abandoned. He develops those things that should be developed. He realizes those things that should be realized.”

analyzed: atha mahā jana kāyaḥ āgaccheyya kuddāla piṭakam ādāya
translated: Now suppose a great many people came along bringing shovels and baskets,

original: ‘mayaṁ imaṁ gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ pacchāninnaṁ karissāma pacchāpoṇaṁ pacchāpabbhāran’ti.
analyzed: mayam imam gaṅgam nadim pacchāninnam karissāma pacchā poṇam pacchā pabbhāranti

analyzed: tam kim maññatha bhikkhave
translated: What do you think, bhikkhus?

original: api nu so mahājanakāyo gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ pacchāninnaṁ kareyya pacchāpoṇaṁ pacchāpabbhāran”ti?
analyzed: api nu saḥ mahā jana kāyaḥ gaṅgam nadim pacchāninnam kareyya pacchā poṇam pacchā pabbhāranti
translated: Would that be enough to make the river Ganges slant, slope, and incline to the west?”

analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: “Why is that?”

analyzed: gaṅgā bhante nadī pācīna ninnā pācīna poṇā pācīna pabbhārā
translated: “Because, venerable sir, the river Ganges slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

original: Sā na sukarā pacchāninnaṁ kātuṁ pacchāpoṇaṁ pacchāpabbhāraṁ.
analyzed: sā na sukarā pacchā a ninnam kātum pacchā a poṇam pacchā pabbhāra
translated: It is not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.”

original: Yāvadeva pana so mahājanakāyo kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.🔽“Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāventaṁ ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ🔽maggaṁ bahulīkarontaṁ rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā ñātisālohitā
analyzed: yāvat eva pana saḥ mahā jana kāyaḥ kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati  evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhum ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventam ariyam aṭṭhaṅgika  maggam bahulīkarontam rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā mittāḥ vā amaccāḥ vā ñātī vā ñāti sālohitā
translated: but only to the extent that the great crowd would be exhausted and worn out.”

analyzed: vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhum pavāreyyu
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is developing the Noble Eightfold Path and when he has developed the Noble Eightfold Path, kings or royal ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or kinsmen, invite him to accept wealth, saying:

original: ‘ehambho purisa, kiṁ te ime kāsāvā anudahanti,
analyzed: eham bho purisa kim te ime kāsāvāḥ anudahanti
translated: ‘Come, good man, what can you do with these dirty ochre robes?

analyzed: kim muṇḍo kapālam anusacarasi
translated: Why go about shaven and with a bowl, like a fake ascetic?

original: Ehi, hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu, puññāni ca karohī’ti.
analyzed: ehi hīnāya avattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohi iti
translated: Come, turn back from this ascetic practice and enjoy wealth, use wealth, do meritorious deeds.’

original: So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: saḥ vata bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bahulīkarontaḥ sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It is impossible, bhikkhus, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who is developing the Noble Eightfold Path and who has developed the Noble Eightfold Path should abandon the training and return to the lower life.

analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Yañhi taṁ, bhikkhave, cittaṁ dīgharattaṁ vivekaninnaṁ vivekapoṇaṁ vivekapabbhāraṁ taṁ vata hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: yat hi te bhikkhave cittam dīgharattam viveka ninnam viveka poṇam viveka pabbhāram tam vata hīnāya avattissati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It’s impossible for a mind that’s long been inclined toward, devoted to, and habituated to solitude to turn back to the lower life.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāveti ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaroti?

analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam pe sammāsamādhim bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim

original: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ uddhambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ayaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
analyzed: imesam kho bhikkhave pañcannam uddhambhāgiyānam sayojanānam abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ayam ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggaḥ bhāvetabbaḥ ti
translated: “This is the noble eightfold path that leads to the cessation of the five higher fetters.”
